header_summary:
Recent discussions across various Bitcoin development mailing lists have highlighted significant milestones in the software's evolution, marking the availability of new release candidates for Bitcoin Core versions 29.2rc2, v30.0rc3, and v28.3rc1. These updates, accessible for testing and review, are critical steps toward finalizing the upcoming versions of Bitcoin Core, with comprehensive details available on the [Bitcoin Core website](https://bitcoincore.org) and the project's [GitHub repository](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin). Each release candidate encompasses improvements and changes aimed at enhancing the stability, security, and performance of Bitcoin Core, urging the community's participation in testing to ensure a smooth transition to their final releases.

In parallel, the discussions also delved into theoretical and technical discourses related to Bitcoin's potential as a financial Schelling point and the implementation of Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) for managing storage devices. The debate led by authors like micah541 and ZmnSCPxj explored the complexities of Bitcoin's position in financial systems and proposed innovative approaches to data integrity and security through TEEs. These conversations underline the ongoing efforts to address Bitcoin's scalability, security challenges, and its broader implications in the evolving landscape of digital currencies.

Moreover, the discourse extends to practical considerations on software development and the security architecture of storage solutions, emphasizing the importance of community involvement in refining and securing Bitcoin Core. As these discussions unfold, they not only contribute to the technical fortification of Bitcoin Core but also enrich the collective understanding of Bitcoin's role and resilience within the broader context of cryptocurrency and blockchain technology.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 29.2 Release Candidate 2 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 29.2rc2 is now available for testing.
- The update and release notes are accessible via the Bitcoin Core and GitHub links provided.
- This release candidate aims to improve Bitcoin Core before the official v29.2 launch.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 30.0rc3 release candidate is available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v30.0rc3 is now available for testing and review.
- Comprehensive release notes and a detailed testing guide are provided to assist contributors.
- Community testing is crucial for the stability and security of the final version 30.0 release.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.3 Release Candidate 1 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core's latest release candidate, v28.3rc1, is now available for download.
- Preliminary release notes are accessible, highlighting the changes and improvements made.
- The update is aimed at developers and participants in the Bitcoin ecosystem for testing and feedback.

recent_posts.title: A Game-Theoretic Approach to Bitcoin’s Valuation in Equilibrium
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's potential as a financial Schelling point entails a paradox of power dynamics.
- Efforts to monopolize Bitcoin could emerge, challenging its stability through power consolidation.
- Bitcoin's security paradoxically relies on its potential for failure amid adoption and stability challenges.

recent_posts.title: Persisting Mutable Storage Inside The "T"EE
recent_posts.summary:
- The debate examines TEE-based versus conventional redundancy approaches for secure data storage management.
- TEEs enhance simplicity and reliability in storage operations, omitting private key storage to reduce risk.
- Emphasizing operational simplicity and security, TEEs offer a flexible solution against unauthorized access and data integrity threats.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v29.2 release candidate available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core's latest release candidate, version 29.2rc2, is now ready for download.
- Users and developers can access it via provided links for testing and contribution, respectively.
- If testing goes smoothly, it will be officially released as version 29.2.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Mempool Validation and Relay Policies via User-Defined Scripts
authors: [BIP Proposal] Mempool Validation and Relay Policies via User-Defined Scripts Aiden McClelland
active_posts.summary:
- Aiden McClelland proposed a modular mempool/relay policy BIP for Bitcoin community review.
- The proposal aims to resolve relay policy conflicts without requiring various node forks.
- McClelland faces challenges creating the BIP's reference implementation due to a C++ hiatus.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Limit ScriptPubkey Size >= 520 Bytes Consensus.
active_posts.summary:
- Brandon Black proposed making over 520-byte ScriptPubkeys in Bitcoin invalid.
- The proposal aims to enhance network security and reduce size without losing key functions.
- It balances innovation with security, and feedback is invited on this evolving topic.

active_posts.title: On (in)ability to embed data into Schnorr
active_posts.summary:
- AdamISZ analyzes embedding data in Schnorr signatures, questioning its security without key disclosure.
- Embedding data might compromise a UTXO set's security by revealing the associated private key.
- He invites critiques on his analysis, available on GitHub, to explore cryptographic implications further.

active_posts.title: Sharing block templates
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin nodes and miners are adopting new mempool policies like full replace-by-fee.
- Compact block relay has significantly minimized block propagation times and reduced orphan rates.
- Alternatives like weak blocks and template sharing enhance network efficiency and robustness.

active_posts.title: Response to Pieter Wuille's StackExchange Answer Re: Nuking the Opreturn Filter
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin fee estimation is complex due to unpredictable miner actions and block timings.
- Efforts to standardize mempools may endanger Bitcoin by promoting censorship and centralization.
- A call for accepting inherent uncertainties in Bitcoin's transaction process is emphasized.

active_posts.title: Eclipsing Bitcoin Nodes with BGP Interception Attacks
active_posts.summary:
- A stealthier BGP hijacking variant exposes significant Bitcoin network vulnerabilities, enabling eclipse attacks.
- Attackers manipulate BGP routes to intercept Bitcoin traffic, enabling potential abuses like double spending.
- Proposed mitigations include leveraging networking data for defense and enhancing Bitcoin Core with traceroute capabilities.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP 2 revival and rework
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- An individual suggests "Share Alike" be required for BIPs but faces licensing issues.
- CC0 is recommended for BIP licensing, with MIT/BSD or CC-BY for attribution concerns.
- BIP 2 supports various licenses but prefers less restrictive ones, aiming for progression.

today_in_history_posts.title: Single channel on mobile clients
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Multiple phone channels for third-party payments introduce management and risk issues.
- Users prefer simplicity over managing channels, impacting app design decisions.
- Developers face a choice between single or multiple channels based on user needs.

today_in_history_posts.title: CVE-2024-38365 public disclosure (btcd `FindAndDelete` bug)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Niklas Gögge and Antoine Poinsot found a significant flaw in older Btcd software versions.
- Their discovery led to a corrective update in version 0.24.2 to align with Bitcoin Core rules.
- The issue's resolution involved community coordination and was publicly disclosed on September 20, 2024.
